awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Debonding of Interfaces in Thermal Spray Coatings
awd_abstract_narration:
This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award will support research that will contribute new knowledge related to a manufacturing process, which will advance the progress of science and enhance national health and prosperity.  This research program studies thermal spray coatings, which are a thin layer of metal that is melted and sprayed onto a surface in order to improve the durability and performance of the part or component. These coatings have numerous benefits and applications, in particular in the automotive industry. Thermal spray coatings have the potential to replace lead-based liners in engines and chromium-based plating materials used in a number of applications. To move this technology to commercial applications, however, fundamental scientific knowledge about the coating performance and its linkages to processing conditions is needed. This GOALI award supports fundamental research to provide the needed knowledge for the optimum design and manufacture of thermal spray coatings. The new knowledge which will result from this research will enable the design of coatings for a variety of applications, reducing cost, weight, and environmental impact over current technologies. This work is performed in collaboration with an industrial partner, Fiat Chrysler Automotive, and Sandia National Laboratories, further enhancing the economic impact of the research. 

The goal of this project is to discover fundamental knowledge pertaining to the delamination of thermal spray coatings in built-up systems. Results from novel experimental insights will be used to formulate a new model to predict delamination of thermal spray coatings. A fracture mechanics-based model informed with a statistical description of the microstructure will be developed and used to predict the debonding of thermal spray coatings. The researchers seek to quantify the strength of adhesion, the fatigue life of the coating itself, and the stresses necessary to initiate delamination of the coating from coated surfaces. The university-industry-national laboratory collaboration will provide unique capabilities as well as valuable educational experiences for the students involved in the research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
This grant focused on thermal spray coatings (see Figure 1), which are the result of a manufacturing process that applies a thin layer of molten metal to a surface in order to improve its durability and performance. There are many benefits to using thermal spray coatings in various applications. For instance, in the automotive industry, the pistons within the engine currently have a lead liner that functions to lengthen the life of the engine. These lead liners, though, are heavy and take up a significant volume of the engine. If the lead liners could be replaced by a thin coating of metal that had similar, if not more advantageous properties, this would enable automotive companies to redesign the pistons to be more efficient, leading to lower fuel costs for consumers and fewer greenhouse gas emissions. Additionally, thermal spray coatings are a technology that can replace chromium plating, the manufacturing of which is both widely used and carcinogenic. This award supported fundamental research to provide needed knowledge for the design of thermal spray coatings.

The primary challenge solved by this project was characterizing the microstructure of a thermal spray coating. Optical images, such as Figure 1, show a heterogeneous material structure that is composed of voids, un-melted particles, oxide layers, and the lamellar structure of the re-solidified metal layers. Prior to this work, there was no method to characterize the observed features. Thus, this research served to combine ideas from computer science, machine vision, analytical geometry, and finite element theory to create a novel, efficient feature identification methodology. This new approach was applied to libraries of thousands of images of thermal spray coatings in order to reconstruct their three-dimensional structure and to provide analysis of how process parameters (such as the temperature, spray velocity, spray distance, etc.) influence the formation of different structures within the thermal spray coating. An example of the feature identification process is shown in Figure 2, in which the algorithm was used to identify features internal to the thermal spray coating.

This project was a unique collaboration between academia, industry, and a national laboratory. As such, results of this work have already been implemented in order to improve the design of internal combustion engines at Fiat Chrysler Automotive. Further results from this research will benefit the U.S. economy, health, and society. Lastly, the experimental facilities developed to validate the modeling in this research are currently being used as a new STEM outreach project to provide area high school students with a hands-on understanding of different mechanical engineering concepts such as strain and fatigue.

 


Last Modified: 05/15/2023
Modified by: Matthew R Brake

Images (1 of )
  • Optical image of the microstructure of a thermal spray coating, showing the lamellar structure of the thermal spray coating (grey) on top of the aluminum substrate (light grey). Included in the thermal spray coating are voids (black), and oxides (dark grey).
    Thomas Ivanoff
    Copyrighted
    Matthew R Brake
    Sample Thermal Spray Coating Image
  • An example application of the new characterization algorithm applied to an image of a thermal spray coating. Red lines indicate some of the identified features, including unmelted particles (spheres), and oxidation layers (dark grey). For clarity, some identified features have been omitted.
    Senyo Ahadzie
    Copyrighted
    Matthew R Brake
    Identified thermal spray coating features
